They are asking for a loan so the can purchase clothes, jewelry, sugar, rice, soft drinks, etc., and others need to get material to create their products like fabric, blenders, etc.

Each participant receives approximately G 900,000 ($190 USD) each.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité “Luchando por el Progreso” nació con el contacto de unas de las integrantes de otro comité de la misma zona que decidió formar su grupo.

Las clientas trabajan en distintos tipos de actividades, como venta de frutas, ropas, lencerías, comidas rápidas, helados, otras tienen despensas donde venden productos de primera necesidad como azúcar, arroz, harina, gaseosas, jugos, panificados, etc.

Solicitan el crédito para poder adquirir mercaderías como , ropas, lencerías, azúcar, arroz, bebidas, etc., otras necesitan materiales para realizar sus actividades como telas , licuadoras, etc. Cada integrante lleva aproximadamente G. 900.000 ($ 190) cada una.

loans.use: Purchase clothing, jewelery, sugar, rice, juices, fabric, blender, etc.

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr:
Aged 35, Mrs. Adjovi T. is the mother of four children and lives in the village of Atsansi-Djita (in the Vo prefecture). She is very dynamic and has been in the corn business for more than 15 years. However, her lack of funds means that she is unable to grow the business and meet the expectations of her customers. In order to increase the size of her business, she is requesting funding of $250 to set up a consistent supply of corn and thus avoid stock shortages.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Agée de 35 ans, Madame T. Adjovi est mère de quatre (4) enfants et vit dans le village d’Atsansi-Djita (P/Vo). Très dynamique, elle exerce le commerce de maïs depuis une quinzaine d’années. Mais le manque de financement fait qu’elle n’arrive pas à rendre florissante son activité et satisfaire les attente de sa clientèle. Pour agrandir la taille de son commerce, elle sollicite un financement de $250 pour faire un stock consistant de maïs afin d’être à l’abri de toute rupture de stock.

loans.use: Corn supplies

loans.name: Mak

texts.en: Mrs. Mak N., 46, is married with eight children. She works as farmer growing a variety of vegetables and typically earns $3 a day in profit. Her husband, Mr. Prak Ren, 47, is a rears pigs and makes about $1 of profit a day. Three of her children live away from home, three are garment workers earning $100 each a month and two others are students. This couple hopes to borrow $600 to purchase construction supplies to renovate their house.(Mrs. Mak N. and her husband is not available for picture. The photograph shows their sons.)

loans.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to renovate their house.

loans.name: Rose's Upendo Group

texts.en:
Rose is 30 years old and is a married woman with 1 4 year old child. Rose started her business in 2006. She works everyday from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Rose has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Deodata and Mariam.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es:
Juan José Almaraz has been working as a taxi cab driver for 6 years in order to cover his family expenses and make his own money. He is married to Maricela de la Rosa Álvarez, who works as a nurse.

He is currently requesting a loan of $500 USD, which he will repay in 6 months, so that he can make his cab look more presentable.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan José Almaraz es taxista oficio que practica desde hace 6 años para poder solventar los gastos de su familia y tener sus propios ingresos. Es casado, su esposa se llama Maricela de la Rosa Álvarez quien trabaja como enfermera.

Actualmente solicita un crédito por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses que invertirá en la imagen de su carro y así tener más presentable su taxi.

loans.use: Improve taxi cab

location.town: San Nicolás de los Garza, Nuevo León

loans.name: Bahrinisso.

texts.ru:
Bahrinisso K. lives in the town of Vahdat. She is 42 years old, married, and has 6 children. Her husband went to work in Russia while she stayed at home with her children. She works with livestock and sells milk and newly born calves. She now wants to take out a loan and buy a cow. This will increase the number of her livestock and she will be able to obtain more milk. She plans on repaying the loan within 15 months.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva volunteer.

Косимова Бахриниссо проживает в городе Вахдат. Ей 42 года , она замужем и имеет 6 детей. Муж уехал на заработки в Россию. А она со своими детьми осталась у себя дома. Занимается разведением крупно-рогатого скота. Продает молоко и вновь родившихся телят. Сейча хочет получить кредит и купить корову. Это поможет ей увеличить поголовье скота и получать больше молока. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 15 месяцев.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Momo

texts.en:
Momo K. is 46 years old. She is married with five children. Her husband is a worker but his income is not sufficient to support the family. Thus, ten years ago, Momo began selling clothing. As she had always liked sales, it went well after the business was started, and she has continued selling clothing since then.

With the profit from her business, she takes care of her beloved children. As a rule Momo travels to the neighboring town, Istaravshan, to purchase new goods. She tries to choose merchandise of good quality and attractive prices which allows her to keep her clientele.

In July Momo is planning her next trip to Bishkek. With this purpose in mind, she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1000 for the term of 12 months. She will spend the loan money on new summer goods for kids and women. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales, to earn more, and to meet the needs of her children. With your help this will be possible. Momo promises to pay the loan on time and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing new summer clothing for kids to increase the range of goods she offers

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana is a stupendous mother and persistent woman with three children, the oldest of whom now lives on his own. Currently her efforts are concentrated on the two younger children who are still in school. For the past ten years she has dedicated herself to farming activities, cultivating corn and potatoes, as well as raising cuyes (guinea pigs). Ana’s wish is to improve her next harvest, which depends greatly on the planting. For this reason, she is asking for a loan to invest into preparing her lands and purchasing fertilizer and alfalfa seeds for her cuye farm. Let’s support this woman who strives to excel.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Ana es estupenda madre y mujer perseverante, tiene 3 hijos, D. los cuales el mayor vive ya solo, ahora sus esfuerzos están concentradas en los dos menores que están en edad escolar. Ella se dedica desD. hace 10 años a las actividades agrícolas, cultiva papa y maíz, también se dedica a la crianza D. cuyes, el deseo D. Ana es mejorar su próxima cosecha, la cual sabe que depenD. mucho D. la siembra, es así que solicita un préstamo que serán invertido en la preparación D. sus tierras D. cultivo comprando abono, fertilizantes y semilla D. alfalfa para su granja D. cuyes. Apoya a esta mujer decidida a tener éxito.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers and seeds for her farmland; also alfalfa for her guinea pigs.

loans.name: Akouét&eacute

texts.fr:
Né à Lomé en 1974, Monsieur K. Akouété Yves vit actuellement à Toulassi Condji à Attitogon du côté de sa femme et ses quatre enfants. Instituteur de profession, il accompagne son travail avec le commerce.

En période d’abondance, il achète les céréales qu’il stocke pour une revente. En cette période de pénuries, Monsieur K. Yves voulant s’ouvrir sur d’autres marchés de céréales, sollicite un crédit pour s’approvisionner en maïs surtout.

Après la vente, il dégage un revenu qui lui permettra de mieux s’occuper de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in Lomé in 1974, Mr. Akouété Yves K. presently lives in Toulassi Condji in Attitogon with his wife and his four children. A teacher by profession, he has a commercial business on the side.

In periods of plenty, he buys cereals which he then stores for re-sale. As there are presently shortages, Mr. K. would like to be open to other grain markets, so he is requesting a loan, most especially to stock up on corn (maize).

After the sale, he will earn an income which will allow him to better support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Storing and re-selling cereals

loans.name: Verónica Asunción

texts.es: Doña Verónica es casada, con una hermosa familia de cinco hijos, con edades de 6, 8, 9,10 y 15 años de edad, habitan en el barrio Casimiro Sotelo, tiene 38 años de edad, y su esposo trabaja como soldador. Doña Verónica trabaja con su esposo en la administración del taller de soldadura que iniciaron con capital propio desde hace quince años, ella es la encargada de control de inventario y de las compra de materia prima, también ayudan su hijo de quince años y dos trabajadores. Esperan que el negocio pueda seguir creciendo como hasta ahora lo ha hecho, y así poder dar servicios a más clientes y mejorar el servicio de los clientes que están con ellos. Necesitan hacer una inversión en su vivienda como es la instalación del techo para eso necesitan comprar perlines y zinc es por eso el motivo del préstamo
texts.en:
Verónica is 38 years old and is married with five beautiful children ages 6, 8, 9, 10 and 15. Her husband works as a welder and they live in the Casimiro Sotelo neighborhood. Veronica works with her husband in the administration of the welding shop which they established with their own capital 15 years ago. She is in charge of inventory control and of purchasing prime materials. Her 15 year old son and two workers also help at the shop. They hope that the business can continue to grow as it has been until now so that they can provide more services and improve the services to their clients. They need to invest in their home by installing a roof which is why they need this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install a roof in part of their home.

loans.name: Regina Namwanje's Group

texts.en:
Regina is the leader of a 5-member group. She is a 38-year-old widow with 3 children aged between 18 and 13. All three children go to school. She rents a three-room house where she is staying with four people. Regina doesn't take care of any additional family member. They do have electricity but no running water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Regina deals in second-hand clothes and goes around door-to-door looking for customers. On average she can sell to 10 people, and she buys the clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.

Regina has been in this business for five years and has managed to educate her two children up to tertiary institution. Her major challenges are the rainy season, seasonality, and feeding the family is at times difficult. Regina plans to use this loan partly for her business and another part to pay school fees for her children. She is aspiring to get a permanent shop for her business and also to educate her children up to university.

loans.use: To increase the inventory for her business

loans.name: Nurat

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Nurat S. from Mwanza. She is married with one four-year-old child. Nurat has been running a maize flour business since 2006. A typical maize business is a stand on the side of the road where maize is often piled high in baskets. Customers can scrutinize the quality of the product before purchase and can specify the exact amount they would like. Maize is very important to the Tanzanian culture because maize is used to make one of their staple dishes, ugali, which is made solely of maize flour and water. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week. Nurat currently earns about 200 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD in order to purchase maize in bulk. Nurat thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase maize in bulk

loans.name: Maritza

texts.en:
Maritza is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank. She lives with her daughter and her common-law husband, who works as a taxi driver. Maritza sells cheese and fruit in the city of Ayacucho. She buys the fruit in Lima (nine hours from Ayacucho) and brings it back in a rented truck to sell. The cheese is produced in rural areas around Ayacucho, so Maritza travels to rural markets to buy cheese, then brings it to Ayacucho to sell. She has been in this line of work for so long she can’t remember when she started. 

Maritza is requesting a loan of 1400 soles to buy seasonal fruit, such as mangoes, pineapples and bananas, in Lima.

Maritza’s goal for the future is to build her own home and open another business selling clothing (since clothing doesn’t spoil).

loans.use: To buy mangoes, pineapples and bananas

loans.name: Imelda

texts.es: Imelda tiene 37 años, está conviviendo con su pareja y su hija de 6 años. Siempre la caracterizó el arduo trabajo de agricultora que realizaba junto a sus padres a quienes apoyaba en su trabajo y en su hogar, desde hace un año colabora con su pareja en las actividades agrícolas, las que realizan en sus pequeñas  parcelas de terrenos que poseen, donde siembran papas, alverjas y otros productos agrícolas. Para Imelda la agricultura es una actividad económica que le viene dando grandes satisfacciones, ya que sus cosechas son vendidas rápidamente a grandes comerciantes, los que comprar variedades de sus productos agrícolas para luego venderlos en los mercados mayoristas. Sin embargo, la dificultad son los costosos precios de los abonos. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y para pagarlo con puntualidad seguirá trabajando duramente. Con el dinero que solicita comprará semilla y abonos para iniciar una nueva siembra  que cosechara el próximo año.
texts.en:
Imelda is 37 years old and lives with her common-law husband and her 6 year old daughter. She was always characterized by the hard agricultural work she performed with her parents, whom she helped in their jobs and in the home. For the past year, she has collaborated with her husband in doing agricultural work. They have small parcels of land in their possession where they plant potatoes, peas and other agricultural products. Agriculture is an economic activity that gives Imelda great satisfaction because her crops are quickly sold to large retailers. They buy a variety of her products to sell at wholesale markets. However, a difficulty [she faces] is the high cost of fertilizer. This is her first loan with MFP, and she will continue to work hard in order to pay it in a timely manner. With the money from this loan, she will buy seeds and fertilizer to start planting a new crop for next year.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Mrs. Janet A. as shown in the picture is a resident of barangay Danao, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She is married and blessed with three children. Like any other people who live in barangay Danao, her primary source of income is fishing.  Her fishing business  sustains everyday needs and  meet the rising cost of  education for her children. 


While her children are still young, Janet wants to insure her children’s future. Janet also wants to raise her children well. To make her dream come true, Janet and her husband need an amount of PHP 50,000 to be used as additional capital for fishing and to purchase their own fishing boat. 


As Janet looks forward to have a good life, able to send her children to school until they  finish college, to have enough to sustain their everyday needs to make improve their way of living. All of these will hopefully be realized if they improve their fishing business..

loans.use: to purchase new pumpboat  to be used as a fishing boat

loans.name: Sabina's Group

texts.en:
N. Sabina, “Jjaja Gonzaga” as she is referred to by her friends and family members, is the leader of the group in Mubende. She has had a business of making pancakes since 1943, when she started with 20 cents and now she is able to cater for her family, especially her grandchildren.

She says that she was introduced to her lending group by well-wishers who saw the burden ahead of her in caring for her family. She received her first loan to reinvest in her business and now she is doing well. She is also a small-scale farmer growing food mostly for home consumption, while before she had enough for sale. Sabina has been able construct rental houses by using her loans and savings and this is also helping her with her home welfare. She needs another loan to help with buying more flour and cooking oil for her pancake business.

loans.use: More flour and cooking oil for her pancake business.

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.es:
Dionisia es socia del Banco Comunal Los Sauces de Compañía, Paulina vive en la comunidad de Compañía que se encuentra a 40 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Dionisia es casada, tiene 64 años y 12 hijos de los cuales 1 vive con ella, Dionisia compra tara, cochinilla, tuna, también alquila terrenos de donde cosecha tara, sus productos los vende a los intermediarios.
Dionisia necesita un préstamo de 700 soles dinero que será invertido en el pago del alquiler de terrenos.
El sueño de Dionisia es mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Dionisia is a member of the community bank “Los Sauces de Compañía”. She lives in the village of Compañía, located 40 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Dionisia is 64 years old, married, and has 12 children, one of whom lives with her. Dionisia buys tara plants, cochinilla (a type of insect), and prickly pears that she then sells to middle-men. She also rents some land where she grows the tara plant. Dionisia needs a loan for 700 soles that she will invest in paying for her rented land. Dionisia’s dream is to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Land rental

loans.name: Augusta

texts.es:
Nuestra socia es la sra. AUGUSTA, ella tiene 49 años de edad y es casada, ella nació en la provincia de Urubamba, en pleno corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, tiene 2 hijos de 24 y 22 años de edad y están estudiando en la etapa superior.

La socia alterna sus labores domésticas con la dirección de su pequeña tienda abarrotes ubicada en su misma casa, de este modo junto a sus esposo dan a sus hijos una mejor educación y desean que sus hijos sean profesionales, ella necesita el préstamo para poder comprar productos no perecibles y de este modo implementar mas su tienda abarrotes, para tener mejores ingresos.

La socia se compromete a hacer efectivo el pago de su préstamo en el tiempo programado y de manera total quedando muy agradecida por la oportunidad que le brindaron de hacer realidad sus sueños personales.
texts.en:
Augusta is 49 years old and married. She was born in the province of Urubamba, in the heart of the sacred valley of the Inca. She has two children, 22 and 24 years old, studying in higher education. She juggles housework with running a small grocery store in her own house with her husband in order to provide a good education to their children. She hopes that they will become professionals. She needs a loan to buy non-perishable goods and improve her grocery store in order to raise her income. She promises to pay the loan back as scheduled and is entirely grateful for the opportunity you are providing her to make her dreams come true.

Translated from Spanish by Shanti Singh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for her grocery store

loans.name: Man Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Man Kumari K. is a tailor in the town of Kuleshwor. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like kurta sulwar, blouses, ladies long dresses, makhshi and others. Before starting her own business, Mrs K. took a six-month training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near her locality.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to use the shop's income for self improvement and for her children's education. In Nepal the cost of good education is very high.

Her husband's name is Shyam K. and he is a house painter. She has one son and one daughter. Both of them are now studying in the higher level.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Saba

texts.en:
M. Saba is a married mother of two children. She has spent all her life in touch with the land since her parents and grandmother taught her how to farm. Agriculture and livestock are her passions, and she is highly motivated as these are the source of livelihood for her family. Her husband is also a farmer and helps her with the business. She raises young cows and bulls until they are grown enough to be sold. Her dairy-producing cows are well-fed and cared for at the stables she has constructed in her home. She nurtures her animals with such care that she has a name for every animal. She would like to expand her business and purchase more young cattle. To reach her aspirations, Saba calls out to your generous hearts to receive the loan that she is requesting.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase young cattle

loans.name: Cristhian Gerardo

texts.es: El joven Cristian Gerardo López Z. , tiene la edad de 28 años , habita en el barrio Juan Ramón Padilla en la comunidad de Ticuantepe, junto a sus padres , los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida , desde hace un año , el inicio las ventas de camisetas , gorras , stiker , entre otros accesorios , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es la falta de financiamiento , ya que tiene una demanda superior a su alcance , el inicio esta actividad con su propios esfuerzos , el trabajaba como cocinero en los estados unidos y ahorro para poder ser el mismo jefe de su negocio . Ahora  con las ventas antes mencionadas quiere incrementar su pedido .El financiamiento lo quiere para la compra de camisetas, stiker y otros producto variado que vende lo cual espera con este tener mejores venta y mejores utilidades el cual se beneficiara en el crecimiento comercial.
texts.en:
The young man Cristian Gerardo L. Z. is 28 years old, lives in the Juan Ramon Padilla neighborhood of the Ticuantepe community, together with his parents. His plans are to improve the living conditions of his family. A year ago he started selling tee shirts, caps, decals and other accessories. His major difficulty is the lack of financing. There is a greater demand for his products that he can achieve. He started this business on his own. He used to work as a cook in the US, and saved to be able to be his own boss in his business. Now, with the before mentioned sales he wants to increase his orders. The loan is to be for the purchase to T-shirts, decals and other products that he sells. He hopes to have better sales and higher profits and benefit from the growth of his business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of T-shirts, caps, decals and other varied products.

loans.name: Las Divinas Group

texts.es: El Grupo “Las divinas” es un grupo representado por el señor Carlos y conformado por 12 personas dentro D. las cuales existe un parentesco familiar entre la señora Lizeth y Liliana que son hermanas, pero con actividades económicas independientes, vienen D. familias amplias como lo demuestra la fotografía ya que alguna D. las socias se encuentra con su esposo e hijos pequeños. Dentro D. las actividades que realizan los señores para el ingreso diario esta la venta D. juguetes, cosméticos por catálogos, ropa, comida y abarrotes en tiendas D. barrio. Dentro del marco competitivo las socias tienen una amplio mercado por lo que no les preocupa la competencia. El destino del financiamiento es para la compra D. insumo y herramientas que coadyuve al incremento D. sus ingresos para poder brindarles a sus familias una mejor calida D. vida. A pesar D. ser un grupo relativamente nuevo ya tienen experiencia en grupos solidarios debido a financiamientos con entidades similares a la fundación Agrocapital quien les brinda la confianza y un apoyo económico para mejorar sus ingresos y la calida D. vida D. sus hogares.
texts.en:
The Las Divinas Loan Group is represented by Señor Carlos and consists of twelve people, among whom there exists a family relationship between Señoras Lizeth and Liliana who are sisters but whose finances are separate.They come from large families, as the the photograph shows, since some of the members may be seen with their spouse and small children. Among the activities these members are engaged in for their daily income are: selling juices, cosmetics catalog sales, selling clothing, or prepared food, or selling groceries in neighborhood stores. Within the competitive framework, the members have a large market and so competition does not worry them. The objective of the loan is to buy items of consumption and tools that would help them to increase their incomes in order to be able to proviD. their families with a better quality of life. In spite of being a relatively new group, many members of this group have experience in solidarity group lending through other institutions that are similar to AgroCapital. Their solidarity group experience has helped to give them confidence and also economic help to improve their earnings and in turn the quality of their lives and homes.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating Capital

loans.name: Mele

texts.en:
Mele T., 41, is married with five children.  She has three years of experience running a taro plantation and vegetables business. She sells to the village people and the public three days per week. 

She has one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~180 USD).  

SPBD loans are Mele’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Mele is one of the best savers in the program and she has been doing well with her first loan. Part of her loan will be used for renovation.

loans.use: Purchase timber for house improvement, gromozones and weedkiller.

loans.name: Lidia Esther

texts.es: Lidia Esther es originaria de la comarca La Peña donde habita junto a su familia, es apoyada por el papá a las actividades productivas, ya que como alternativa de trabajo se dedica a la produccion arrocera de baja escala, lo que le brinda ingresos que le permiten el sostenimiento familiar, es para la solicitante de sumo interes participar como socia del trillo de arroz, ya que esto le permitira mejorar sus condiciones de vida personal y familiar, es madre soltera, lo que le ha obligado a incorporarse al trabajo productivo.
texts.en:
Lidia Esther is from the La Peña region, where she lives with her family. Her father supports her in her work, and rather than having a job, she cultivates rice on a small scale. This generates income which allows her to support her family. She is extremely interested in becoming a part-owner of a rice thresher, because this will make it possible for her to improve the standard of living of her family, since she is a single mother, which is why she has to work.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Kamsvaag, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 30% share in the construction of a rice thresher

loans.name: Wahibe

texts.en:
Wahibe is a 46-year-old married woman and mother of three children. She has been working as a home-based tailor since 2001 and has twenty years of previous experience in this field.

Today, Wahibe is requesting to borrow $1,200 in order to buy a sewing machine to provide a variety of products for her clientele.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Marbelita

texts.es: La señora Marbelita, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Maria Auxiliadora”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Divorciada, tiene 51 años, 01 que aun depende de ella. Se inicio con un capital de S/. 500.00 y poco a poco fue implementando y ampliando su negocio, lleva varios años dedicándose a la venta de lavavajillas, se encuentra ubicada en el Mercado Central de su Distrito, a diario tiene muy buenas ventas, cuenta con clientes ya fidelizados, que se acercan a su puesto a comprar y encuentran lo que necesitan, para lavar sus vajillas.Se siente muy bien y tranquila, ya que tiene muy buena acogida y sus clientes ya la conocen por sus ventas. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,300.00, comprará mas lavavajillas como: esponjas para platos y ollas, en diferentes modelos y tipos de materiales, de esta manera satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes. Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Marbelita belongs to the "Maria Auxiliadora" community bank in the Tarapoto district in the San Martin province and department. She is divorced, is 51 years old and has one child who still depends on her. She started her business with S. 500 and gradually has been building and expanding it. For many years she has been dedicated to selling dishwashing needs. You may find her located in the Central Market of her district. On a daily basis, she has good sales. She has faithful customers who come to her stall to buy and find what they need to wash their dishes. She feels good and relaxed since she gets a good reception and her customers know her for her sales. With this loan of S. 1,300, she will purchase more dishwashing tools such as sponges for dishes and pots in different styles and types of materials. In this way, she can satisfy the needs of her customers. She is very satisfied with her work. She believes that it is worth the sacrifice to achieve the dreams and goals she has developed in her life. At the same time, she is thankful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for providing supprt to her and other women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase more dishwashing tools such as sponges for dishes and pots.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita P. is from the village of Lutao. She is 44 years old. Angelita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Angelita owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Angelita has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Angelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Angelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, such as hooks and nets

loans.name: Bayanbuu

texts.en: Bayanbuu is 27 years old and lives with his wife and one year old daughter in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city.  He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  His wife is currently working for the police academy as a secretary and their daughter stays at home. Bayanbuu not only takes care of his wife and daughter, but he is also responsible for his mother and terminally ill younger brother. After saving money from his previous job, Bayanbuu purchased a car which enabled him to start his own transportation business in 2008.  During the last year, he has saved enough money to purchase a microbus which has enabled him to transport more people and goods. Bayanbuu is committed to not only improving the lives of his wife and child, but he is also committed to making sure that his brother has the best care possible. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to buy a newer, more reliable microbus so that his business will become even more profitable.

loans.use: to buy a newer, more reliable mini bus

loans.name: Mina Chojlla Group

texts.es:
Mina Chojlla es un grupo de 15 señoras alegres y dinámicas, que se reúnen cada catorce días, en el Centro Focal Los Andes, actualmente están juntas aproximadamente tres años.
Valeriana Añaya, casada y madre de 3 niños, es una de las integrantes y cuenta que está en el grupo hace 1 año y ½, ingresó al grupo por invitación de su sobrina y porque necesitaba capital para  su negocio, ella vende comida, inicialmente trabajaba como cocinera y quiso independizarse hace 2 años. Vende todos los días en un lugar cerca de su domicilio, actualmente necesita del préstamo para comprar capital fijo, es decir, mesas y sillas.
Las demás integrantes también tienen sus propios negocios como el tejido de chompas, producción de zapatos, venta de ropa y alimentos secos, todas necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería o materia prima.
texts.en:
Mina Chojlla is a group of 15 happy and dynamic women. They meet every 14 days in the Los Andes Community Center. They have been together for approximately three years. Valeriana Añaya is married and has three children. She is one of the members, and she says she has been in the group for one and a half years. She joined the group because her niece invited her, and she needed capital for her business. She sells food. She first worked as a cook, and two years ago she wanted to be independent. She sells everyday in a place close to her home. She currently needs a loan to buy tables and chairs. The rest of the members also have their own businesses like weaving sweaters, making shoes, and selling clothes and dried food. All of them need the loan to buy merchandise or raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise and raw material

loans.name: Kanouya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kanouya de l’association Dounkafa est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, une des préfectures de la région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 28 ans et au moins 3 enfants.
Les femmes du  groupe Kanouya  font la restauration et le commerce d’articles divers comme activité génératrices de revenus. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Kanouya de l’association Dounkafa ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle ils sont à leur premier prêt. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat de condiments alimentaires, du riz et d’autres ingrédients pour la restauration qui est très rentable pour ces femmes. 
Elles vendent leurs plats alimentaires généralement au comptant et à une clientèle riche te variée.
Les femmes du groupe Kanouya comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 15.000 FCFA à 30.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
'The Kanouya group belonging to the Dounkafa Association, made up of married women from the town of Tominian, a prefecture of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and have an average age of 28 and on average, at least 3 children each.

The women of this Kanouya group sell cooked food and various retail items in order to earn income. To make their businesses more productive, the members of this Kanouya group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan. This loan will be used to buy condiments, rice, and a lot of other ingredients for cooked food, a business which earns these women a good income. They sell their cooked dishes generally for cash to a varied clientele. Each of the members of the Kanouya group expects to make a monthly profit of 15,000 to 30,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for making cooked food to sell

loans.name: Margretena

texts.en:
Margretena P. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock rice and maize flour to sell.  Margretena is 40 years old and married to a nurse. She has two children who both go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for maize flour and rice.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock rice and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Rang

texts.en: Rang L., 20, is married with a young child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and child. To make a living, she and her husband produce traditional Cambodian drums for tourists, collectively earning an income of US $7 per day. Her husband always helps his wife in the business. L. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, L. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase a new motorbike to use for transporting materials to produce drums.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita tiene 26 años y vive muy feliz con su esposo (Rudy), de 27 años, que se dedica a su  chacra de plátanos. Con él tiene 2 inquietos, pero hermosos hijos; Jack de 8 y Anais de 2 años, juntos viven en una acogedora y cómoda casa ubicada en la zona selva del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la venta de “salchipollo” -platillo compuesto de papas fritas con pedazos de pollo frito - en la puerta de su casa. Para ello, acondicionó el pequeño patio que tenía e le hizo un pequeño techo de paja, así el ambiente rústico garantiza la presencia a sus habituales comensales. Cada día es una lucha constante para salir adelante, pues Margarita debe levantarse temprano para preparar a sus hijos para el colegio; en la tarde cocina y casi al anochecer prepara todo para empezar a trabajar, ya que su negocio tiene bastante demanda durante la noche.
Esta actividad le genera buenas ganancias, pues en el corto tiempo que viene laborando ya ha podido comprar una refrigeradora, y con ella además de los platillos, prepara también chupetes de hielo que vende a sus calurosos clientes que buscan refrescarse a como de lugar. 
Como Margarita es una mujer emprendedora piensa para el futuro implementar una tienda de comestibles, además de vender comida, pues sabe que está próxima a construirse una carretera cerca de su casa y los trabajadores buscarán dónde alimentarse.

Esta es la sexta vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y quiere seguir progresando para lograr cumplir con las metas que se ha propuesto para sacar adelante a sus hijos. Tiene pensado invertir el dinero que solicita en la compra de una balanza, pues también quiere empezar a vender carne de pollo durante el día, y con lo que le reste del día preparará sus porciones de “salchipollo”.
texts.en:
Margarita is 26 years old and lives happily with her husband Rudy, who is 27 years old and a banana farmer. They have two restless, but beautiful children: Jack (age 8) and Anais (age 2). They live in a cramped, but comfortable home located in the Peruvian jungle.

Margarita sells “salchipollo” (a dish consisting of French fries and pieces of fried chicken) from the doorstep of her house. In order to do this, she had to rearrange her small patio and install a thatched roof to provide a rustic atmosphere for her diners to enjoy. Every day is a constant struggle to get ahead, so Margarita wakes up early to prepare her children for school. At dusk, she begins preparing the food that she needs for her business so that she can meet the demand that she encounters throughout the evening.

Margarita’s business has been generating good revenues in the short time that she has been in operation. She was able to buy a refrigerator and dishes. In addition, she makes popsicles to sell to customers looking to get relief from the heat. As a businesswoman, Margarita has plans to open a snack shop where she can sell prepared food. She knows that a highway will be built near her house, so she wants to feed those workers who are looking for a place to dine.

This is her sixth loan with MFP. Margarita wants to continue forward toward the goals she hopes to accomplish on behalf of her children. With the money she requested, she plans to purchase a scale. She also wants to start selling butchered chickens during the day and use what she has left over to prepare salchipollo.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a scale

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal “La Juleñita” desD. hace 2 años atrás, del distrito D. Juli, provincia D. Chucuito, departamento D. Puno, tiene 50 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 04 hijos, todos son independientes. Ella estudió primaria incompleta, se dedica a la compra y venta D. abarrotes. En sus ratos libres venD. tejidos en forma ambulatoria.

Rosa nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, lo que le sirvió para aumentar su capital.

Ella solicitará un crédito  D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar  aceite, arroz, azúcar.

Su sueño para el futuro es vivir tranquila sin preocupaciones con su esposo, pues ya no tienen a quien mantener. 

Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal son los ahorros y las reuniones con las socias
texts.en:
Rosa, 50, has been a member of the “La Juleñita” communal bank, which is in Juli district, Chucuito province, Puno department, for the last 2 years. She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are independent. She completed elementary school and she is a grocery merchant. In her free time she peddles woven items. She tells us that with her first, 300 new sol, loan from the Manuela Ramos Movement, she increased her capital. She now needs 300 new soles to buy oil, rice and sugar. Her dream for the future is to live with her husband in peace and without worries since they no longer have anyone to support. What she likes best about her communal bank is the savings and the get-togethers with her fellow members.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy oil, rice, sugar.

loans.name: Nabi

texts.en:
Nabi is 54 years old and he is a hard worker. He is marrid with 3 children. Nabi has been farming since 2004. He has six years of experience, and he has been able to support his family by learning how to take care and manage his crops in the short growing season. 

Nabi aspires to have more farming equipment and more farming supplies so that he can work his land much more productively. Due to lack of funds has not been able to do so. He is asking for a loan to purchase more farming supplies, such as herbicides, fertilizer and other necessities, in order to appropriately manage his crops, and, in the end, make a profit. This request is in support of making his dream come true, and Nabi is asking for help from your generous heart. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase supplies such as fertilizer

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en: Anatalia E. is a married Tanzanian woman. She runs a business selling charcoal in Kiwalani, Dar es Salaam. Charcoal is the main source of domestic power in this developing country due to the high price and instability of electrical power. She purchases the charcoal from wholesale suppliers and sells it to retail customers for domestic consumption. She managed to buy a plot of land in Dar es Salaam, and meets her family’s daily needs from the income generated by her business. She needs a loan of 1,500,000 Tanzanian Shillings (TZX) to diversify the business.

loans.use: to diversify her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Cement, rock, and sand

loans.name: Viioleta

texts.en:
Viioleta N. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Viioleta is married and has six school-age children. Viioleta is now starting a business buying and selling coconut. She has previous experience in selling food as she has managed a small food stall in her village for many years.

In 2009, Viioleta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Viioleta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI.  Viioleta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Viioleta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bunchhoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Bunchhoeun P. is 58 years old and he is a villager who lives in Phlov Trei village in Kandal province. He is a teacher in the local school where he receives a small salary to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Rann Nov, is a mango middleman in the local market.

Mr. Bunchhoeun P. now is requesting a loan to purchase more mangoes to enlarge his wife’s business. With this loan, he hopes to increase her income to improve the family living conditions.

This couple does not have any children. His wife is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase more mangoes for his wife's business

loans.name: Mrs. Noen Chek Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Chrey Young village in Kandal province, eighteen people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Noen C. is a village bank president who has been selected by the group members who will use this loan for different purposes. She and her husband are vegetable sellers. Since their business is going well, they want to expand. Thus, Mrs. Noen C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. This couple has six children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factories and the others are attending the local public school. All the members are shown in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable to sell.

loans.name: Dora Judith

texts.es:
la sra. Dora Judith C. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular y granos básicos, tiene diez años de dedicarse a este tipo de negocio. Dora atiende personalmente por lo tanto es bien administrado y durante todo este tiempo se ve que lo ha manejado muy bien,  dicho negocio esta ubicado en el desvió de la calle que conduce a Planes, Las Trojes. este lugar es bien transitado por los Alumnos que se dirigen a la escuela que se encuentra a escasos metros de su negocio.  
Es una persona muy reconocida en la Aldea y se ha sabido ganar la clientela lo que le a generado mayor demanda de los productos que ella vende en su negocio.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y surtir su pulperia, la ganancias que obtenga las necesita para cubrir con los gastos de su hogar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dora Judith C. makes a living by selling common goods and basic grains, which she has done for ten years. She attends to her store personally, for which it is well run. It is easy to see that during this whole time she has managed it very well. Her business is located on a detour off the street that leads to Planes, Las Trojes. This place is well traveled by students as they make their way to school, which is very close to her business. Dora is a very well known person in her town, and she knows how to earn her clientele, which has generated a greater demand for the products that she sells. She will use this loan to purchase more merchandise to stock her store, and thereby earn more income to cover her domestic expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, soft drinks, dairy products, butter, sugar, coffee, tortillas, bread, pills, toilet paper, sanitary wipes, cookies, soup, and pasta

loans.name: C2361 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Emelyne is 26 years old and is married with children: the first born is 7 years old and the last one is 4 years old.

Emelyne is the representative of a group which is called Abishyizehamwe in the local language. This group contains five members, all of them women.

Emelyne owns a small shop selling various styles of clothes. She is serious woman in her business and is organized as well. She has an experience of one year in her daily activities. Her small shop is open from eight in the morning to five in the evening, every day except Sunday.

Emelyne and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses through purchasing more products.

With this loan Emelyne will be able to employ one person from her community as the business will be expanded. This will attract more customers which will help her to obtain more profits. With the profits she expects to earn, she will be able to save money for the future and to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nga

texts.en:
Nga T. T. was born in 1980. She is married with two children who are still young. She is a farmer breeding pigs and poultry. Her husband is a driver. Sometimes she and her husband go to work together.

They have a monthly income of about 6,000,000 Vietnam Dong (VND). They always try to work hard.

Since 2006, she has participated in SEDA and repaid punctually. For this loan, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to repair her house.

010115500009

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina N. is from the village of San Vicente. She is 29 years old and married with one small child. To make a living, Paulina provides transportation services to local community members. Paulina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Paulina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for payment of her motor. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Paulina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: payment of her motor

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi T. sells crates of eggs at Abura.  Esi has received junior high education.  She is a single parent who takes care of three children. She provides the needs of her children with the income she makes from her sales. Her loan will be used to buy additional crates of eggs to be able to also supply to those customers who demand a larger quantity. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a store house where she can keep the eggs.

loans.use: buy additional crates of eggs

loans.name: Novel

texts.en:
After Novel A. has proven her capability to run and manage a hog-raising business, she now wants to venture into another kind of business. Through a much larger loan she is requesting through Kiva for the second time, Novel plans to open a “sari-sari” store, which will basically sell small quantities of various foodstuffs, grocery items and beverages. 

“Sari” in a native dialect of Antiquenos means "variety." This is just a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage not far away from the owner’s house. Items sold through this business bring convenience to people in the village, especially those who live far away from the town proper where the market is located.

Novel’s vision now becomes clearer because she has been able to inspire her irresponsible husband to cooperate through her previous business. Together with him, she will continue to work hard in achieving her dreams for her children.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of inventory for her "sari-sari" variety store

loans.name: Eulalia Florinda

texts.es: La Sra. Eulalia, tiene un puesto de venta de golosinas en el patio de una Escuela, donde vive y trabaja de portera en el turno de la tarde, dicha escuela se encuentra ubicada en la calle 21 de la zona de Calacoto, ella tiene una hija de 12 años, quien estudia por la mañana y en la tarde le ayuda  en la venta, la señora tiene una antiguedad de 15 años en el trabajo, al margen de la venta ella percibe un  salario mensual por ese servicio, ahora el crédito que solicita es para comprar mercaderia que traerá de la ciudad de Oruro como dulces, galletas, refrescos, etc, además de las golosinas, comprara mercaderia en ropa de cama, ella vino recomendada por una cliente antigua.
texts.en:
Eulalia has a sweets stand on the patio of a school where she lives and works as a caretaker during the afternoon shift. This school is located on 21st Street in the Calacoto zone. She has a 12 year old daughter who studies in the morning and helps with sales in the afternoon. Eulalia has been doing this work for 15 years. Aside from the sweets sales, she receives a monthly salary for her caretaker service. The loan that she requests is to purchase merchandise that she will bring from the city of Oruro, such as candy, cookies, refreshments, etc. In addition to the sweets, she will buy merchandise such as bedding. Eulalia has been recommended by a long-time client.

Translated from Spanish by Rachael Mossey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Buyanja Promotion A, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Hard working Sharotte K. has been operating a new garment business selling women's suits, wedding gowns and more for 20 years in Buyanja town. This determined and innovative lady has by all standards tried to maintain the business that she started with little capital when she was a housewife.

Her main business limitation is having a small stock of clothing, so she is requesting this loan to purchase a greater variety of garments that will attract more customers. The additional profits from an expanded line will enable her to meet her family's expenses as she considers starting up a poultry business.

Sharotte belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her business

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso A. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 45 years old. Celso is married and has a 1-year-old child. To make a living, Celso owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Celso has been engaged in his business for over 25 years. He also owns a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages.

Celso joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celso has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Celso is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Celso from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Juan Hermogenes

texts.es:
El Señor Juan Hermogenes G. S. tiene 46 años está separado de su pareja por más de 10 años es padre de 3 hijos  a los cuales ayuda y ayuda en su educación; el trabaja actualmente como moto taxista  en el sindicato“10 de Noviembre”  en el cual esta hace mas de 6 años como socio activo, el servicio que brinda es rentable por la alta cantidad de personas que solicitan este servicio por la facilidad,  rapidez y eficiencia. El sindicato cuenta con paradas y turnos para cada afiliado, en diferentes puntos de la localidad de Ivirgarzama donde las personas acuden para solicitar dicho servicio.

 El cliente solicita el credito para la compra de una nueva motocicleta, debido a que la que tiene actualmente ya cumplió su ciclo de trabajo y de esta forma poder brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes lo que le permitirá también mejorar sus ingresos consecuente mente mejorar su calidad de vida.
 Cabe señalar que el señor Juan Hermogenes G. S. se apersono a CIDRE a solicitar su préstamo luego de que sus compañeros de trabajo le Comentaron de las buenas condiciones crediticias con las que trabaja nuestra institución
texts.en:
Juan Hermogenes G. S. is 46 years old. He’s been separated for more than 10 years and has three children whom he supports and provides an education for. [Juan] works with the “10 de Noviembre” union as a moto-taxi driver, and has been an active member for more than six years. His services are profitable because of the quality of people who request this service, given its convenience, speed, and efficiency. The union provides stops and shifts for each member, in different locations around Ivirgarzama, where people gather to request services. [Juan] is requesting this loan in order to buy a new motorcycle because the one he has is at the end of its lifecycle and a new one will allow him to provide better service to his customers. It will also allow him to improve his income and quality of life. We should mention that Juan approached CIDRE for a loan after his coworkers told him of the favorable loan terms that our institution provides.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en: Felisa A. is a married woman who lives in the seaside town of Dauin, Negros Oriental, just across from one of the Philippines' famous dive sites, Apo Island. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Ricarte A., who is 73 years old, works as a photographer to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have a 24-year-old child. Felisa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Felisa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,500 PHP, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing 18,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy more merchandise to resell in her general store. She plans to continue to save up for future home repairs. Felisa A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer C. is from the village of Centro 2, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Jennifer is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jennifer owns & operates a general store, primarily selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Jennifer has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jennifer joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jennifer has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jennifer is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jennifer from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Lona

texts.en: Lona T. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions and is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell.  Lona is 20 years old and is married to a builder. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Virgen De Fatima Group

texts.es:
Sra. Ana Marìa S. M., socia D. la Alcancia "Virgen D. Fàtima" (en la foto, es la primera empezando por la izquierda; està sonriente y entusiasta por la inaguraciòn D. este grupo).
Ana Maria lleva años en este negocio, sus principios fueron duros; tras el nacimiento D. su hija Kimberly. 
Ana Marìa empezò a repartir periòdicos junto a su esposo Don Cèsar Baltazar Castro, pues por la necesidad D. mantener el hogar trabajaban desD. tempranas horas D. la madrugada, ya que ellos hasta hoy tienen que hacer cola para recoger sus periòdicos. Poco a poco fueron ahorrando y juntaron para comprar un kiosko para trabajar cerca D. casa; asì trabajaban y ahorraban hasta lograr comprar un segundo kiosko que pudieron ubicarlo en una zona màs cèntrica y con mas concurrencia D. pùblico. Con el esfuerzo D. ello, su hija este año podrà festejar su cumpleaños numero 15 a mediados del presente mes, en una ceremonia sencilla al lado D. sus seres queridos.

El prèstamo que han solicitado es para incrementar y diversificar sus revistas; ademas D. adicionar la venta D. golosinas.
texts.en:
Sra. Ana Maria S. M. is a member of the Virgen D. Fatima community bank.  (Ana Maria is on the left in the photo; she's smiling and excited to be part of this new group.)

Ana Maria has operated a business for several years.  The first years, after the birth of her daughter, Kimberly, were tough.  She started out delivering newspapers with her husband, Don Cesar Baltazar Castro.  In order to pay the family's bills, they had to start very early in the morning because even now they have to get in line before dawn to pick up their papers.  Little by little, they saved and pulled enough money together to buy a kiosk near their house; then they worked and saved until they had enough money to buy a second kiosk that they set up in a more central location so they could capture more passers-by.  Because of the business, they can celebrate their daughter's 15th birthday later this month, an important milestone for a young Peruvian woman, and one they'll celebrate with those closest to them.

Ana Maria will use part of the loan to increase the number and titles of magazines she sells.  She will use the other  part of buy snacks that she will resell.

loans.use: Stock products for retail business.

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio S. Jr. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 53 years old and married. To make a living, Julio owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soft drinks and school supplies. Julio works hard to build his business.

Julio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julio has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Julio is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen K. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (a mother and father).  Maureen has a business of African clothing. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Maureen sells her products door-to-door, by means of retail.  

Esther has requested a loan of 500000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of African clothing. She also generates additional income through selling locally made ghee (butter fat made out of milk). The main business challenge(s) for Maureen include rainy season and ever increasing prices of African clothing. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a permanent business premises and also to build her own house and to educate her children up to university.  Maureen lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy rolls of African clothing

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn Q. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 29 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and convenience foods in the local community. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Merlyn joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as instant noodles and convenience foods. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell such as instant noodles and junk foods

loans.name: German

texts.es: El Sr. German cliente que se encuentra en el primer ciclo dentro de la institución  vino por recomendación de otros clientes,  el  señor German vive en la zona de Rosas Pampa, es viudo , tiene casa propia vive con sus dos hijas menores de edad se dedica  como actividad principal al negocio de la compra y venta de herramientas, equipos de sonido , radios , Dvds , televisores  y otros (por ocasión)  en la feria 16 de julio el alto siendo ambulante, los días jueves y domingos. Los demás días se dedica al trabajo de la plomería y a la crianza de animales domésticos  los cuales representan una entrada económica , el destino del crédito es para incrementar su capital de trabajo invertirá en la compra de herramientas y aparatos de sonido, esta muy agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: German is requesting his first loan with this partner, and is recommended by other clients. German, a widower, lives in his own house in the Rosas Pampa neighborhood with his two daughters who are minors. His main activity is running a business buying and selling tools, sound equipment, radios, DVDs, televisions, and occasionally other items at the 16 de Julio / El Alto Market from a street kiosk on Thursdays and Sundays. The other days he works as a plumber and raises domestic animals, which provides a source of income. The purpose of the loan is to increase his working capital by purchasing tools and sound equipment. He is very grateful to the partner for their support.

loans.use: Purchase of sound equipment and tools.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Safia lives in a small city called Kasur, which is located in Pakistan and known for its leather industry. She is 37 years old and lives with her family in a two-room brick house in the area named Basti wanikaan. She supports her family financially by making paranday (an ornament used to tie back hair). She sells them to different cosmetics shops to earn an income. She is the mother of six children, three sons and three daughters. Only her second daughter, who is 7 years old, is managing to get an education by attending school. 

Safia's husband, whose name is M. S., is involved in a shoe-soles stitching business. He makes contracts with different shoe making factories and fills their orders to earn an income. His business is well established and he has been operating this business for the past twenty-five years. Her three sons and eldest daughter also help their father in his business, by stitching shoe soles. 

Safia has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy needles and thread in bulk quantities, which will help him fill larger orders and make more income. Safia is sure that her husband will definitely be able to expand his business with the help of an investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy needles and thread for her husband's shoe-sole stitching business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is from the town of Tuburan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Susan owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of food products in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Susan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Susan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy M. is from the village of Serran, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 55 years old. Daisy is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Daisy owns & operates a business venture running a sari-sari (variety) shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Daisy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
